titleStmt.title: The King of Denmarck. The King of France, the King of Spain, the states of Vevice [sic] navies on the seas, intended for England. With the cause of their comming, and their intents. As also the just number of all their navies, and the souldiers with them, and where each navie lyes. Likewise, the Danes and Italians resolution concerning His Majesty. And the names of the captains of each navie, Captain Keevalo Dunous for the Danes. Captain De Sunae Bewit for France. Captain Don Pedringano for Spain. Captain Hupah Fenao for the Italians.

As also the just number of all their navies, and the souldiers with them, and where each navie lyes. Likewise, the Danes and Italians resolution concerning His Majesty. projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE KING OF DENMARCK. THE King of France, The King of Spain, The States of Venice Navies on the Seas, intended for ENGLAND. WITH, The Cau≈øe of their comming, and their intents. As al≈øo the ju≈øt Number of all their Navies, and the Souldiers with them, and where each Navie lyes. Likewi≈øe, the Danes and Italians Re≈øolution concerning His Maje≈øty. And the Names of the Captains of each NAVIE, Captain Keevalo Dunous for the Danes. Captain De Sunae Bewit for France. Captain Don Pedringano for Spain. Captain Hupah Fenao for the Italians.

div.head: THE KING OF DENMARKS Navie.
div.p:
AFter the confu≈øive di≈øtractions in this Kingdome of England, intelligence being ≈øpread abroad to mo≈øt neighboring Nations, concerning his Maje≈øty mo≈øt particularly, and among≈øt others the King of Denmarke hearing of the ≈øame, fir≈øt convocated a Councell, and when he perceived the pronene≈ø≈øe, and eager readine≈ø≈øe of the Danes: who≈øe propen≈øity was greater then he expected, he forthwith by the unanimous con≈øent of his Coun≈øell, concluded to rai≈øe a Fleet, which he would ≈øend over to the Engli≈øh Coa≈øt re≈øpectively. They elected immediatly Keevalo Dunous to be their chief Commander, and ≈øet forward with 75 ≈øayl the 13 of this pre≈øent month of March, but they ≈øtayed two dais on ≈øhore, expecting a good wind, and ≈øo they ≈øet forward the 15. day having a good gale, tryumphing in great pomp, &c. There are above 40000. Danes in all, and it is ≈øuppos'd, that their number will be ≈øhortly augmented. They lye now at the Coa≈øts of Ireland, and they ≈øent a me≈ø≈øage to the King of their loyalty to his Maje≈øty, and the cau≈øe of their comming and intents were onely to vindicate the
abu≈øive injuries done again≈øt his Royall per≈øon: but the King (who≈øe care and vigilancy extends to the pro≈øperous ≈øecurity of his ≈øubiects, who≈øe clemency is adorned with ≈øuch patience, that he had rather ≈øuffer wrong him≈øelf, then bath the ≈øame in cloudy tevenge to the detriment, and hazard of his Kingdomes) would not accept of their ≈øervice, and di≈øcreetly denyed their entertainment.

But they continue at the Iri≈øh Coa≈øt ≈øtill, and if they hear not further an≈øwer from His Maje≈øty ≈øpeedily, they will return again into their Country, which God grant they may, as ≈øoon as they plea≈øe.

div.head: The King of Frances Navie
div.p:
THe French King hearing of the turbulent divi≈øions in Eng ‚Ä¢ and, and ≈øome abu≈øes done to his Brother, known particularly by the private information of a dear Friend, and moved by the ≈øame to a≈ø≈øi≈øt his Maje≈øty, ≈øummoned a Navie, under the command of Captain De Sunae Bewit, and intended to ≈øet forward for England. The certainty of this News is credible, a though there hath been ≈øome ementitious Pamphlets that have heretofore bin fictitiou≈øly publi≈øhed, intimating that the French fleet was provided long ≈øince, bvt it was not intended before now of late: and although the other was a lye, would this were ≈øo too, but it is too
certaine. They have fifty ≈øix ≈øaile, and about thirty thou≈øand ≈øouldiers, loaded like wi≈øe with great provi≈øion of Armes.
They lye in the narrow ≈øeas, and were di≈øcryed by two Engli≈øh Merchants ≈øhips, who e≈øpied them there, and reported it at London for truth.

And noe que≈øtion but they will be at England very ≈øuddatnely, if they be not timely prevented, for be≈øides that number, twice as many more are re≈øolved to ≈øecond them, and doe now waite in readine≈ø≈øe: they come likewi≈øe to maintaine his Maje≈øties cau≈øe; but I hope his Maje≈øtie will neither accept of their ≈øervice, nor have any cau≈øe to v≈øe them.

div.head: The King of Spaines Navy.
div.p: THe Spaniard (like a crafty For) harh alwayes weighted for his prey on England, which hath beene the ≈øole object of his greedy intentions. Witne≈ø≈øe fir≈øt that formidable and invincible Armado in 88. which was ≈øufficiently potent to have bla≈øted the whole Kingdome at one brunt, had not the divine protection averted it from vs.

Now likewi≈øe the King of Spain perceiving a ≈øedition, and various confu≈øion in the Kingdome, hath provided a fleet con≈øi≈øting of 23. ≈øhips, under the Command of Captain Don Pedringano, to the number of 8000. ≈øouldiers, waiting on the Seas for his opportunity. The≈øe ≈øhips were e≈øpyed a hundred leagues di≈øtant from the Spani≈øh Coa≈øt, ≈øome think his intent hereby is for the defence of his own Country, but that ≈øeems improbable, in regard it is ≈øo far remote from their own ≈øhore: others think verily that his meaning is to aid, and a≈ø≈øi≈øt his Maje≈øty upon ju≈øt occa≈øion: but in my opinion I conceive his intent is to wait rather for his own prey, and watching his opportunity: for tho≈øe that are too officious in warlike affairs, e≈øpecially in a forraign Kingdome, will rather regard their own ends, then any others, for they will alwais turn to the ≈øtronge≈øt ≈øide: But I hope all his evill intentions, and private ≈øtratagems will fall on his own head.

div.head: The States of Venices Navie.
div.p:
THe Italians ≈øeriou≈øly under≈øtanding ≈øome wrongs offered unto his Maje≈øty, acquainted the States of Venice with the ≈øame. Who immediatly ≈øate in Councell about it, and after ≈øome mature deliberation concluded to ≈øet out a Navie to a≈ø≈øi≈øt his Maje≈øty, which was unanimou≈øly confirmed, and a≈ø≈øented unto their fleet con≈øi≈øteth of 48. ≈øhips, under the Commad of Captaine
Hupah Fenao, there being at the lea≈øt 36000. ≈øouldiers, being al≈øo provided with ≈øtrong ammunition of arms: they lye now within le≈ø≈øe then 40. leagues from the Downs, and are ≈øuddenly intended to appropinquate the Engli≈øh Coa≈øt, being all unitely re≈øolved to maintain the Kings own per≈øon from all injuries, or abu≈øes: but I hope the Kings clemency will mittigate their anger, and no doubt, but that His Maje≈øty will not entertain them, having no cau≈øe of any ≈øuch vindication.

COn≈øtancy is an Antidote again≈øt fear: wherfore let us be ≈øincerely con≈øtant in our minds, and we may ea≈øily expell fear from our thoughts. Fir≈øt con≈øtant to God, con≈øtant to our King, con≈øtant to our Parliament, con≈øtant to our ≈øelves, and la≈øtly con≈øtant to truth and equity. The≈øe being truly performed, we need not to fear either any forraign or dome≈øtick enemy, As for the≈øe Navies aforementioned, they may perhaps ca≈øt a repercu≈ø≈øive fear and a≈øtoni≈øhment into the minds of ≈øome: but if we be really true, and con≈øtant in our minds, we need not fear them.

As for tho≈øe injuries, and abu≈øes done to His Maje≈øty, which they intend, and are re≈øolved to vindicate, for my own part, I am ignorant of any; which if there were, I believe His Maje≈øty is more loving, and tender over his Subjects, then for ≈øome particular abu≈øe to depopulate the whole Kingdome in revenge
of the ≈øame. And the Parliament are ≈øo judicious in their pious way, and in all their mature Coun≈øels, that if any known, and unju≈øt injury ≈øholy be offered unto his Maje≈øty, they would (I am confident) according to Equity and Iu≈øtice correct the ≈øame. And they are ≈øo vigilant, and carefull for the ≈øafety, and ≈øecurity of the Kingdome, that if any enemy ≈øhould violently oppo≈øe us, they would bee ≈øpeedily provided for them in defedce of the Realm. God grant that the King and Parliament may ≈øo unitely accord, and corre≈øpond together, that no cau≈øe of Fears, and Iealou≈øies, that no ≈øu≈øpition of injuries, may be reflected on either.
